correct_answer.context: 7/8 is greater than 5/8 because both fractions have the same denominator (eighths), and 7 parts is more than 5 parts

steps.dialogue: Compare these two fractions using only the notation.

correct_answer.context: 5/12 is less than 11/12 because both fractions have the same denominator (12), so we compare numerators: 5 < 11

steps.dialogue: Look at this comparison. Why is it true?

workspace.description: Comparison statement showing 5/8 > 2/8

options.text: Both fractions show eighths. 5 > 2, so 5/8 is greater.
The bigger the denominator, the bigger the fraction.
The bottom number tells us which fraction is greater.
The fraction with more total pieces is greater.

correct_answer.context: When fractions have the same denominator, compare numerators - 5 pieces is more than 2 pieces of the same size

steps.success_path_dialogue: That's right. That explanation is correct.

steps.dialogue: Look at this comparison. Why is seven-tenths greater than three-tenths?

workspace.description: Comparison statement showing 7/10 > 3/10

options.text: The fraction with more total pieces is greater.
The denominator is the same, so if 7 > 3, then 7/10 > 3/10.
The bigger the denominator, the bigger the fraction.
The bottom number tells us which fraction is greater.

correct_answer.context: When fractions have the same denominator, we compare numerators. Since 7 > 3, then 7/10 > 3/10.

steps.success_path_dialogue: That's right. That explanation is correct.

steps.dialogue: Look at this comparison. Why is 9/12 greater than 4/12?

workspace.description: Comparison statement showing 9/12 > 4/12

options.text: The bottom number tells us which fraction is greater.
The bigger the denominator, the bigger the fraction.
Both fractions show twelfths. 9 > 4, so 9/12 is greater.
The fraction with more total pieces is greater.

correct_answer.context: When denominators are equal, the fraction with the larger numerator is greater

steps.success_path_dialogue: That's right. Same-sized pieces, but 9/12 has more of them.
